reasoning: The critique targets a specific, but non-exhaustive, pillar of the post’s case for higher substitutability (ρ closer to 0): the claim that rapid “reconfiguration” of production/research processes could happen in days/weeks with AGIs. If that claim fails, it meaningfully weakens one route by which compute bottlenecks might not bite early, but the post offers several other independent reasons (e.g., algorithmic efficiency increasing experiments, non-frontier experimentation, multiple routes to progress), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The argument’s strength is moderate: historical cases (electrification/factory redesign) do support institutional and organizational inertia as a real constraint, but the analogy is not decisive for AI R&D specifically (which may be more internally reconfigurable, less regulated, and potentially AI-run). Most claims are plausible and largely correct, though some overgeneralization (“never been a pure speed-of-thought problem”) reduces correctness slightly. It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Historical production reorganizations faced institutional bottlenecks that fast thinking cannot bypass
